Introduction

In the understanding of older individuals, family growth (History Tracers, 2024) ocurrs through the addition (summing) of new people. This expansion can be viewed as a "journey" towards the family future. Is there something common between these concepts (family and journey?

Common enumeration

When we think about roads, it is natural to consider:

  • The sacbé (plural sacbeoob), also known as "white roads", which connected various Maya cities (Diaz C, H., 2000, p. 22, 27, 28).
  • The Qhapac Ñan, or "beautiful road", a 39.000 km route traversing the Inca Empire (Jurado, Rosario C. V., 2008, pp. 1270 - 1271 ; Unesco - World Heritage Convention, 2009).
  • The Peabiru, an ancient route connecting the Atlantic Ocean to the Pacific Ocean, as described in some chronicles (Borges, A. E., 2006).

Since there are different types of families, we will begin by examining the families proposed by Morgan before delving into the taxonomic group Family (History Tracers (2024): Family).

The numbers we use for counting (History Tracers, 2024) also belong to a group known as natural numbers or positive numbers, represented by ℕ = {0, 1, 2, 3, 4, ...}. While it is possible to exclude zero (0) from this group, we prefer to follow Ribenboim and include it (Weisstein, Eric W, Natural Number).

For both roads and families, counting is applicable. In the case of roads, we move through the natural numbers when counting steps: we start with zero (0) steps, advance to one (1) with each step taken, and so forth. Similarly, for families, we "progress" through the natural numbers when individuals decide to form a family, and we continue to increment the count when a new person is born (or adopted). To express this mathematical progression, we use the symbol + (addition or sum).

Regarding dimensions

Table 1: Sum with numerical systems. The source code is available in GitHub of the project (History Tracers, 2024).

Although we are performing mathematical operations with indigenous numbers, it is important to note that we lack any sources confirming their establishment of these operations.

While table 1 may appear straightforward, it offers essential insights:

  • The first column mentions only numbers because we are generalizing all possible samples, such as steps, people, stars, and fruits.
  • The analysis of what we are summing may not confirm correctness, but it can indicate potential errors. For instance, when adding one bird to one fish, expecting two cats as the final result is unreasonable. Clearly, the samples being added do not belong to the same group or do not share the same dimension. On the other hand, when adding one animal to another animal, we expect having two animals because the generalization unifies the groups.
  • Any number added to zero will result in the number itself, as zero symbolizes an empty concept (Musa, Auwalu, 2014, pp. 46 - 48).
  • Adding one to any number yields the next number in the Natural Numbers sequence.
